personal.name: Louis Follet
personal.title: PhD Student in Quantum Photonics & AI at MIT
bio: I am a PhD student in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at MIT, working in the Quantum Photonics & AI Group under Professor Dirk Englund. My research specializes in AI for Science, quantum optics, and photonics, with a strong focus on leveraging machine learning to tackle complex physics and engineering challenges.

I develop novel physics-informed ML frameworks (PINNs, Neural Operators, Bayesian Inference) to create surrogate models and solve inverse problems in semiconductor fabrication. My work also involves designing and optimizing photonic crystal cavities for quantum information processing and building automated characterization systems that integrate optical metrology with ML-driven data analysis.

research.title: Physics-Informed ML for Semiconductor Fabrication
research.description: Developing novel physics-informed ML frameworks (PINNs, Neural Operators, Bayesian Inference) to create surrogate models and solve inverse problems in modeling fabrication variations in foundry processes. This work enables more accurate prediction and control of manufacturing outcomes.

research.title: Photonic Crystal Cavities for Quantum Computing
research.description: Designing and optimizing photonic crystal cavities for quantum and information processing through advanced modeling techniques (Guided-Mode Expansion, FDTD) and full-cycle fabrication workflows with GlobalFoundries and AIM Photonics.

research.title: Automated Optical Metrology Systems
research.description: Building automated characterization systems that integrate complex optical metrology with ML-driven data analysis, enabling rapid and high-precision measurements of photonic devices and quantum systems.

research.title: Quantum Spin Defects in 2D Materials
research.description: Contributed to breakthrough research on spin-active defects in hexagonal Boron Nitride films at University of Cambridge, developing Python-based control software and conducting ODMR experiments for quantum sensing applications.
